q: What are common nail problems?
a: Common nail problems include brittle, loose nails that may change color or shape.

q: How long does it take for fingernails to grow back if they fall off after an injury?
a: Fingernails that fall off after an injury should grow back within 6 months.

q: What can I do to look after my nails?
a: You can wear rubber gloves if your hands are often in water or you regularly use cleaning products, clean your nails with a soft nailbrush, apply hand cream to your nails and fingertips regularly, and trim your nails regularly.

q: What should I not do to take care of my nails?
a: You should not cut your nails down the edges or clean under your nails with sharp objects. Also, avoid shoes that pinch your toes, biting or picking your nails, and ignoring fungal infections on your skin.

q: When should I see a GP for nail problems?
a: You should see a GP if a nail has changed shape, changed color, or fallen off and you don't know why. Also, if the skin around your nails has become sore, red, swollen, and warm (paronychia), which may be a sign of an infection or ingrown toenail.

q: When should I see a podiatrist for nail problems?
a: You should see a podiatrist if your nails are too tough to cut or you cannot reach them. Some GPs may be able to refer you to a footcare specialist (podiatrist), or you can also pay to see a podiatrist privately.

q: What can cause nail problems?
a: Nail problems can be caused by injuries, biting your nails, staining your nails, not regularly trimming your nails, your hands often being in water or cleaning products, fungal nail infections, and certain medical conditions or medications.

q: What are some medical conditions that can cause nail problems?
a: Some medical conditions that can cause nail problems include psoriasis, iron deficiency anemia, underactive or overactive thyroid, diabetes, and heart, lung, or liver disease.

q: What does it mean if my nails curve inwards?
a: Spoon-shaped nails that curve inwards (koilonychia) can be a sign of iron-deficiency anemia.

q: What can deep lines or grooves across the fingernails indicate?
a: Deep lines or grooves across the fingernails (Beau's lines) may happen when you're ill, but they should grow out.

q: What are some causes of nail problems?
a: Nail problems can be caused by injuries, biting your nails, staining your nails, not regularly trimming or cutting them at an angle, exposure to water or cleaning products, fungal nail infections, underlying conditions like psoriasis, iron deficiency anemia, thyroid disorders, diabetes, heart/lung/liver disease, and certain medications.

q: Can you show me some pictures of nails with problems?
a:
Sure! Here are some examples:
1. Spoon-shaped nails that curve inwards (koilonychia) can be a sign of iron-deficiency anaemia. (image link)
2. Small dents or pits in your nails can be a sign of nail psoriasis, eczema or alopecia. (image link)
3. Deep lines or grooves across your fingernails (Beau's lines) may happen when you're ill but should grow out. (image link)
4. Fingernails curving over rounded fingertips (clubbing) can be a sign of many serious, long-term conditions. (image link)

q: What are some serious or long-term conditions that nail problems could be a symptom of?
a: Nail problems could be a symptom of serious or long-term conditions such as psoriasis, iron deficiency anemia, thyroid disorders, diabetes, and heart/lung/liver disease.

q: Can medicines cause nail problems?
a: Yes, some medicines can cause nail problems. It's important to check the side effects of any medicine you're taking.
